title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.10.19 | 05-06-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya
segments.summary: The lecture begins with the chanting of traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and the Lord.

segments.key_quote: when Krishna was leaving the palace of Hastinapura there were brahmanas who were glorifying Krishna by chanting Vedic hymns and offering benediction to Krishna
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 19th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on the apparent contradiction of offering benedictions to Krishna, who is the Absolute.

segments.key_quote: Krishna was playing the part of a human being though he is not a human being. He is the Supreme Lord always under all circumstances but he is playing the part of a human being.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's explanation of the verse, highlighting that Krishna was playing the role of a human being as a guest of Yudhishthira, making the benedictions fitting in that context.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is described as nirguna, nirguna means absolute, without any material qualities. So he is not a human being, he has no material relationship with anybody.
segments.summary: The speaker explains why the benedictions were also unbefitting, because Krishna is absolute (nirguna) and doesn't need material benefits, and that He creates the material world for our sake.

segments.key_quote: And we are foolish to desire material enjoyment while we are entitled to sublime spiritual pleasure in his association.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses how humans foolishly seek material happiness instead of spiritual bliss in connection with Krishna, who creates the material world because we insist on trying to enjoy it.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is full of transcendental qualities when it said nirguna doesn't mean that the Absolute Truth Krishna is the absolute personality of God. It doesn't mean when he describes Nirguna that he has no qualities at all.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that 'nirguna' doesn't mean Krishna has no qualities, but rather that He has no material qualities, only transcendental ones, and that the spiritual world is free from the contradictions found in the material world.

segments.key_quote: In the material world, dark complexion people are considered not so beautiful. Whereas fair complexion people are considered very beautiful. This is the main contradiction.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of beauty standards to illustrate the difference between the material and spiritual worlds, and reiterates that benedictions are meant for conditioned souls, not the liberated Lord.

segments.key_quote: the same glorification same sorry same benedictions when they are offered to Krishna when they are offered to Krishna in devotion then they are no longer contradictory they becomes transcendental
segments.summary: The speaker explains that when Vedic hymns and benedictions are offered to Krishna with devotion, they become transcendental and lose their contradictory nature, ultimately glorifying Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Lord Shree Krishna is described as thief and robber he is very famous among his pure devotees as a impatience banter He stealing butter from the neighbor houses at Prindavan early ages childhood pastimes of Krishna he steal butter from the neighboring houses
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of Krishna being called a thief (Makhan Chaur) to illustrate how seemingly contradictory qualities can exist in the Supreme Lord, because everything is applicable to Him.

segments.key_quote: all interactions between Krishna and his devotees in the spiritual world simply result in increased ever-increasing transcendental bliss
segments.summary: The speaker explains that in Vrindavan, Krishna's actions, even stealing, bring pleasure to His devotees, resulting in ever-increasing transcendental bliss, and that everything applied to Krishna becomes transcendental.
